lexUnit.name: reticent.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily

sentence.text: Afterwards he was reticent about the ill-fortune which has plagued him .
The ex-CID officer was more reticent about the perks of the job , more willing to see those offers as the practice in other forces .
Throughout his career Smith was extremely reticent about his personal affairs and shunned publicity .
He was educated privately , and was always very reticent about his early years : he seems to have been largely self-taught in music .
The King , visiting as a private citizen , was reticent about his political ambitions , saying only that he wanted to help Romania .
Now , this week Brian Burnett 's been uncharacteristically reticent about his celebrity musical interview .
Journalists , likewise , scarcely seem reticent in their claims .
As Western Europe 's largest employer , the NHS has been noticeably reticent in the debate .
The hon. Gentleman has been noticeably reticent in this respect in the past .
A few things nettled her : she did not relish being a clearing house for family complaints , for instance , and was carefully reticent on such occasions .
Joan had regaled her with details of the Twelfth Night festivities -- whilst remaining noticeably reticent on the subject of Prince Edward .
Marxists have often been reticent on these questions .
The barrister reacted to a situation created by the judge ; he felt that he must try to convey at once to the jury that his client was not being obstructive or reticent about disclosing a statement .
` Why are they so reticent about announcing it ? "
Harry may be reticent about praising his son -- but Barnsley boss Mel Machin certainly is n't .
